column6: description
A combination of cellular processes that permits survival and growth under specific hydrogen ion concentrations.
A measure of the breadth of hydrogen ion concentrations that a microorganism can tolerate, calculated as the difference between the maximum and minimum viable pH values
A growth tolerance metric measuring the span of pH conditions that support an organism's growth, with a wide range between 5 and 9 pH units. Values ranging from 5 to 9 pH.
A growth tolerance metric measuring the span of pH conditions that support an organism's growth, with a range between 1 and 2 pH units. Values ranging from 1 to 2 pH.
A growth tolerance metric measuring the span of pH conditions that support an organism's growth, with a range between 2 and 3 pH units. Values ranging from 2 to 3 pH.
A growth tolerance metric measuring the span of pH conditions that support an organism's growth, with a range between 3 and 4 pH units. Values ranging from 3 to 4 pH.
A growth tolerance metric measuring the span of pH conditions that support an organism's growth, with a range between 4 and 5 pH units. Values ranging from 4 to 5 pH.
A growth tolerance metric measuring the span of pH conditions that support an organism's growth, with a narrow range less than 1 pH unit. Values with maximum value of 1 pH.
The specific pH at which an organism exhibits maximum growth rate
The specific hydrogen ion concentration at which a microorganism achieves its maximum growth rate and metabolic efficiency.

A pH optimum manifested as maximum microbial growth at hydrogen ion concentrations between pH 8 and 14, characteristic of alkaliphilic or extremely alkaliphilic organisms. Values ranging from 8 to 14 pH.
A pH optimum manifested as maximum microbial growth at hydrogen ion concentrations between pH 0 and 6, characteristic of acidophilic organisms. Values ranging from 0 to 6 pH.
A pH optimum manifested as maximum microbial growth at hydrogen ion concentrations between pH 6 and 7, characteristic of neutrophilic or alkali-tolerant organisms. Values ranging from 6 to 7 pH.

A pH optimum manifested as maximum microbial growth at hydrogen ion concentrations between pH 7 and 8, characteristic of neutrophilic, alkaliphilic, or alkali-tolerant organisms. Values ranging from 7 to 8 pH.
The span of pH values within which an organism can grow
The span of hydrogen ion concentrations within which a microorganism can maintain cellular homeostasis and sustain growth.
A pH range allowing microbial growth at hydrogen ion concentrations between pH 10 and 14, characteristic of extremely alkaliphilic organisms. Values ranging from 10 to 14 pH.
A pH range allowing microbial growth at hydrogen ion concentrations between pH 4 and 6, characteristic of acidophilic organisms. Values ranging from 4 to 6 pH.
A pH range allowing microbial growth at hydrogen ion concentrations between pH 6 and 7, characteristic of neutrophilic organisms. Values ranging from 6 to 7 pH.
A pH range allowing microbial growth at hydrogen ion concentrations between pH 7 and 8, characteristic of neutrophilic or alkaliphilic organisms. Values ranging from 7 to 8 pH.
A pH range allowing microbial growth at hydrogen ion concentrations between pH 8 and 10, characteristic of alkaliphilic organisms. Values ranging from 8 to 10 pH.
A pH range allowing microbial growth at hydrogen ion concentrations between pH 0 and 4, characteristic of extremely acidophilic organisms. Values ranging from 0 to 4 pH.
The ability of an organism to survive exposure to pH values outside its optimal growth range
A measure of the breadth of thermal conditions that a microorganism can withstand, calculated as the difference between the maximum and minimum viable temperature values
A growth tolerance metric measuring the span of temperatures that support an organism's growth, with a wide range greater than 30°C. Values with minimum value of 30 C.
A growth tolerance metric measuring the span of temperatures that support an organism's growth, with a range between 5°C and 10°C. Values ranging from 5 to 10 C.
A growth tolerance metric measuring the span of temperatures that support an organism's growth, with a range between 10°C and 20°C. Values ranging from 10 to 20 C.
A growth tolerance metric measuring the span of temperatures that support an organism's growth, with a range between 20°C and 30°C. Values ranging from 20 to 30 C.
A growth tolerance metric measuring the span of temperatures that support an organism's growth, with a narrow range between 1°C and 5°C. Values ranging from 1 to 5 C.
The specific temperature at which an organism exhibits maximum growth rate
The specific temperature at which a microorganism exhibits maximum metabolic activity and growth rate within its viable range.
A temperature optimum manifested as maximum microbial growth at temperatures above 40°C, typical of thermophilic organisms. Values with minimum value of 40 C.
A temperature optimum manifested as maximum microbial growth at temperatures between 10°C and 22°C, common in psychrophilic or psychrotolerant organisms. Values ranging from 10 to 22 C.
A temperature optimum manifested as maximum microbial growth at temperatures between 22°C and 27°C, characteristic of mesophilic organisms. Values ranging from 22 to 27 C.
A temperature optimum manifested as maximum microbial growth at temperatures between 27°C and 30°C, characteristic of mesophilic organisms. Values ranging from 27 to 30 C.
A temperature optimum manifested as maximum microbial growth at temperatures between 30°C and 34°C, characteristic of mesophilic organisms. Values ranging from 30 to 34 C.
A temperature optimum manifested as maximum microbial growth at temperatures between 34°C and 40°C, characteristic of mesophilic organisms. Values ranging from 34 to 40 C.
A temperature optimum manifested as maximum microbial growth at temperatures below 10°C, typical of psychrophilic organisms. Values with maximum value of 10 C.
The span of temperatures within which an organism can grow
The span of temperatures within which a microorganism can maintain metabolic functions and population viability.
A temperature range allowing microbial growth at temperatures above 40°C, characteristic of thermophilic organisms. Values with minimum value of 40 C.
A temperature range allowing microbial growth at temperatures between 10°C and 22°C, characteristic of psychrophilic or psychrotolerant organisms. Values ranging from 10 to 22 C.
A temperature range allowing microbial growth at temperatures between 22°C and 27°C, characteristic of mesophilic organisms. Values ranging from 22 to 27 C.
A temperature range allowing microbial growth at temperatures between 27°C and 30°C, characteristic of mesophilic organisms. Values ranging from 27 to 30 C.
A temperature range allowing microbial growth at temperatures between 30°C and 34°C, characteristic of mesophilic organisms. Values ranging from 30 to 34 C.
A temperature range allowing microbial growth at temperatures between 34°C and 40°C, characteristic of mesophilic organisms. Values ranging from 34 to 40 C.
A temperature range allowing microbial growth at temperatures below 10°C, characteristic of psychrophilic organisms. Values with maximum value of 10 C.
A measure of the breadth of sodium chloride concentrations that a microorganism can tolerate, calculated as the difference between the maximum and minimum viable salinity values.
A growth tolerance metric measuring the span of sodium chloride concentrations that support an organism's growth, with a wide range greater than 8%. Values with maximum value of 8 C.
A growth tolerance metric measuring the span of sodium chloride concentrations that support an organism's growth, with a narrow range less than 1%. Values with maximum value of 1 C.
A growth tolerance metric measuring the span of sodium chloride concentrations that support an organism's growth, with a range between 1% and 3%. Values ranging from 1 to 3 C.
A growth tolerance metric measuring the span of sodium chloride concentrations that support an organism's growth, with a range between 3% and 8%. Values ranging from 3 to 8 C.
The specific concentration of sodium chloride at which a microorganism exhibits maximum growth rate and metabolic efficiency.
A salinity optimum manifested as maximum microbial growth at sodium chloride concentrations above 8%, characteristic of extreme halophiles. Values with minimum value of 8 % NaCl.

A salinity optimum manifested as maximum microbial growth at sodium chloride concentrations below 1%, characteristic of non-halophilic or halotolerant organisms. Values with maximum value of 1 % NaCl.

A salinity optimum manifested as maximum microbial growth at sodium chloride concentrations between 1% and 3%, characteristic of slight halophiles or halotolerant organisms. Values ranging from 1 to 3 % NaCl.

A salinity optimum manifested as maximum microbial growth at sodium chloride concentrations between 3% and 8%, characteristic of moderate halophiles or halotolerant organisms. Values ranging from 3 to 8 % NaCl.
The span of sodium chloride concentrations within which a microorganism can maintain osmotic balance and cellular functions.
A salinity range allowing microbial growth at sodium chloride concentrations above 8%, characteristic of extreme halophiles. Values with minimum value of 8 % NaCl.
A salinity range allowing microbial growth at sodium chloride concentrations below 1%, characteristic of non-halophilic organisms. Values with maximum value of 1 % NaCl.
A salinity range allowing microbial growth at sodium chloride concentrations between 1% and 3%, characteristic of slight halophiles. Values ranging from 1 to 3 % NaCl.
A salinity range allowing microbial growth at sodium chloride concentrations between 3% and 8%, characteristic of moderate halophiles. Values ranging from 3 to 8 % NaCl.
The percentage of guanine and cytosine nucleotides in DNA
A genomic feature characterized by a guanine-cytosine content percentage above 66.3% in an organism's DNA. Values with minimum value of 66.3 % GC.
A genomic feature characterized by a guanine-cytosine content percentage below 42.65% in an organism's DNA. Values with maximum value of 42.65 % GC.
A genomic feature characterized by a guanine-cytosine content percentage between 42.65% and 57% in an organism's DNA. Values ranging from 42.65 to 57 % GC.
A genomic feature characterized by a guanine-cytosine content percentage between 57% and 66.3% in an organism's DNA. Values ranging from 57 to 66.3 % GC.
